Award.AwardTitle: GRIDS: Graphing Research on Inquiry with Data in Science

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Graphing Research on Inquiry with Data in Science (GRIDS) project is a four-year full design and development proposal, addressing the learning strand, submitted to the DR K-12 program at the NSF. GRIDS will investigate strategies to improve middle school students' science learning by focusing on student ability to interpret and use graphs. In middle school math, students typically graph only linear functions and rarely encounter features used in science, such as units, scientific notation, non-integer values, noise, cycles, and exponentials. Science teachers rarely teach about the graph features needed in science, so students are left to learn science without recourse to what is inarguably a key tool in learning and doing science. GRIDS will undertake a comprehensive program to address the need for improved graph comprehension. The project will create, study, and disseminate technology-based assessments, technologies that aid graph interpretation, instructional designs, professional development, and learning materials.

GRIDS will start by developing the GRIDS Graphing Inventory (GGI), an online, research-based measure of graphing skills that are relevant to middle school science. The project will address gaps revealed by the GGI by designing instructional activities that feature powerful digital technologies including automated guidance based on analysis of student generated graphs and student writing about graphs. These materials will be tested in classroom comparison studies using the GGI to assess both annual and longitudinal progress. Approximately 30 teachers selected from 10 public middle schools will participate in the project, along with approximately 4,000 students in their classrooms. A series of design studies will be conducted to create and test ten units of study and associated assessments, and a minimum of 30 comparison studies will be conducted to optimize instructional strategies. The comparison studies will include a minimum of 5 experiments per term, each with 6 teachers and their 600-800 students. The project will develop supports for teachers to guide students to use graphs and science knowledge to deepen understanding, and to develop agency and identity as science learners.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Graphing Research on Inquiry with Data in Science (GRIDS) project investigated three goals in order to address the assessment and instruction of using graphs to learn more complex ideas in science, therein employing rigorous intellectual merit principles to have the broadest impact for researchers, teachers, and students:

  1. Create and Evaluate a GRIDS Graphing Inventory (GGI) and ensure this instrument?s reliability;

  2. Analyze middle school students? Knowledge Integration outcomes over a three-year period related to constructing and interpreting graphs in order to measure differences in science learning through graphs;

  3. Design and refine instructional materials aligned with the GRIDS Graphing Inventory (GGI) and test their effectiveness in developing middle-school graphing skills to learn science through graphs.

 

The following significant findings were produced as outcomes of this project:

First, the 7-item GRIDS Graphing Inventory (GGI) was developed and tested over a three-year period with changes made along the way to refine its reliability to measure students? abilities to use graphs to learn complex science concepts. This instrument was sufficiently reliable to measure students? science learning when asked to translate graphical representations of data in order to make scientifically-sound claims based on that data. Moreover, the demographic analyses support that the GGI instrument does not place bias on students? background including their gender or native English language status. Combining these findings together for the goal of creating and testing the reliability of the GGI instrument, GRIDS can conclude that the GGI can be effectively and appropriately implemented with middle school aged students to measure their abilities to use graphs to construct arguments about complex and data-rich, standards-aligned middle school science topics

Second, a cohort of 300 middle school students completed the GGI each year, for 3 consecutive years,enabling a longitudinal analysis. The analysis suggests that students? ability to integrate science and graph knowledge into coherent and accurate arguments significantly increased over the 3-year period, having a ?large? impact. Figure 1 below showcases this growth in science-graph knowledge integration.

 

 

GRIDS developed instruction to strengthen graph-science knowledge integration in 10 units across middle school: Thermodynamics, Global Climate Change, Genetics; Photosynthesis, Cellular Respiration, EcoSystems, Plate Tectonics, Graphing Stories, Self Propelled Vehicles, Genetics of Extinction. The GRIDS design and iterative revision of the curriculum used in coordination with the GGI showcased promising results in promoting students? science learning and experimentation skills involving graphs and science learning. 

 

 

For example, in Figure 2 below, we present one such novel inclusion, the Thermodynamics Challenge Experimentation Matrix. During our previous classroom implementations of the Thermo Challenge curriculum unit, we observed many students adopting a perfunctory approach towards using the model (e.g., completing a random subset of tests in a haphazard manner, or running quickly through all the test possibilities to ?complete? the work) rather than taking a more self-directed and reflective approach towards conducting their experiments (i.e., making intentional decisions about which experimental tests to run and why these tests might be useful for improving their understanding).

Based on these observations, we redesigned the model interface to more explicitly promote students in engaging in reflective and self-directed experimentation with the model. Specifically, we made design changes to better support students with the following key scientific practices: planning and carrying out an investigation, using the model to investigate ideas and explanations, and analyzing and interpreting data obtained from the model. The new design feature that supports students with these activities is the experimentation matrix, which allows students to easily view the full range of experimental trials for their planning, investigating and analyzing activities with the model (see Figure 2). 

As can be seen in the figure, the column headers of the matrix indicate the six different materials available for testing (i.e., aluminum, wood, styrofoam, plastic, clay and glass) and the row headers of the matrix show the three starting liquid temperature options (i.e., hot, warm and cold). The resulting 3 x 6 matrix thus allows students to track the 18 possible experiments that they can run with the model. The experimentation matrix and supporting curriculum scaffolds aim to engage students in more directed and deliberate experimentation with the model: Students first use the matrix to discuss and record the key tests they want to run (planning; the matrix logs students? preferred tests as ?starred? experiments), they then use the matrix to select tests to run with the model (experimentation and data collection) and finally, students use the matrix to choose a subset of their collected data for scaffolded graphical analysis and sense-making (interpretation).

Finally other designs in our projects show, such as in Figure 3 below, that automated guidance can support students to refine how they construct graphs. Students modified their understanding of position-time graph shape particularly how slope and direction are represented.
